title: SB 1.18.46 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 28-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: So the reaction of the son of Shamika Rishi Shringi was to become very angry against the king and curse the king to die within seven days.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 46th verse of the 18th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining the context of Shamika Rishi's reaction to his son cursing King Pariksit.

segments.key_quote: He is particularly telling because that king is emperor of the world and his qualifications are being mentioned here by Rishi Shamika. He does not at all deserve to be cursed.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Shamika Rishi's disapproval of his son's curse, emphasizing King Pariksit's high position and the inappropriateness of the punishment for a minor offense.

segments.key_quote: As a duty a king is supposed to perform sacrifices for the protection of welfare prosperity of these citizens of the world.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the duties of a king, including performing sacrifices for the welfare of the citizens, and emphasizes the heavy responsibility associated with ruling a kingdom.

segments.key_quote: Such a responsible king, such a heavy duty he has to perform and his position is so exalted that in his position when he is taken responsibility, it is to be considered that such a king can do no wrong in the sense that even if he does some small mistake.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that a king's position is so responsible that even small mistakes should not be punished, and that kings have specific duties to perform according to the Dharma Shastras.

segments.key_quote: In the Shastras, the duties of all caste and order of society are prescribed. All the qualities of a Kshatriya mentioned in the Bhagavad-Gita, in the 18th chapter, the 43rd verse, it is described, what are the qualifications by which a Kshatriya functions.
segments.summary: The speaker mentions the qualities of a Kshatriya as described in the Bhagavad-Gita and states that Pariksit possessed all those qualities.

segments.key_quote: That's the perfect leader and people have got confidence in this leadership because they are very nicely protected they are provided for they are guided correctly so he is the ideal leader
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the seven Kshatriya qualities mentioned in the Bhagavad-Gita, providing examples of how King Pariksit embodied each quality.

segments.key_quote: Unless the brahmanas are properly situated they cannot lead and inspire and guide the other orders of society the kshatriyas vaishya sudras
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating the injustice of the curse on King Pariksit and emphasizing the importance of Brahmanas being properly situated to guide society.
